page.title: 05ASHTON KEYNES CHURCH
page.content: The Church of The Holy Cross stands at the north west edge of the village. It has a Norman Chancel arch which was widened and raised when William Butterfield restored the building in 1877. The drum shaped Norman font is decorated with chevrons between rows of leaves and honeysuckle. The pointed arches of the nave are thirteenth century, as is the chapel which has a fifteenth century window. The tower is perpendicular with battlements and gargoyles. A nineteenth century marble monument shows Charlotte Nicholas on her deathbed surrounded by her family. Around the Church and Church Farm can be seen the remains of the double moat which is a reminder of the monastry which once stood there.
